study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess patterns of medical cannabis use in patients over 50 and its effects on pain, sleep, quality of life, and co-medication.
results_summary: Significant improvements were noted in pain, sleep, and quality of life, with 45% experiencing clinically meaningful improvements in pain and sleep. Nearly 50% reduced co-medication use, and no serious adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Patients over 50 years of age, predominantly female (66.2%), with pain-related conditions like chronic pain and arthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the longer-term impacts of recreational cannabis markets on cannabis use prevalence and initiation among adolescents and adults in five U.S. states.
results_summary: The study found moderate increases in cannabis use prevalence and initiation among adolescents (12-17), and large increases among young adults (18-25) and older adults (26+), 2-4 years after dispensaries became operational.
population_specificity: Adolescents (12-17), young adults (18-25), and older adults (26+) in Colorado, Washington, Oregon, Alaska, and Nevada.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how vaporized cannabis affects driving-related skills and risk-taking behaviors in medicinal cannabis patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant changes in objective driving-related performance after cannabis consumption, but participants reported reduced self-perceived hazard perception and traffic conflict prediction ability. There was no correlation between objective and subjective performance measures.
population_specificity: Adult medicinal cannabis patients (N=38, mean age=43).
effective_dosage: One dose of prescribed cannabis flower (specific amount not stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of recreational cannabis legalization on prescribing patterns of opioids, NSAIDs, and other pain medications among commercially insured adults in the U.S.
results_summary: Recreational cannabis legalization was associated with a 13% reduction in opioid prescriptions and marginal increases in non-opioid pain medication use. Stronger effects were observed once recreational dispensaries opened, suggesting substitution of cannabis for traditional pain medications.
population_specificity: Commercially insured adults in the U.S.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the in vitro antibacterial activity of ethanol extracts from five hemp cultivars against Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus agalactiae, and Streptococcus dysgalactiae.
results_summary: All five hemp cultivars exhibited inhibitory effects against the tested pathogens, with Santhica 27 showing the strongest antibacterial activity (MIC of 128 μg/mL against Str. agalactiae and S. aureus). Felina 32 and Futura 75 had weaker activity (MICs ranging from 256 to 2048 μg/mL).
population_specificity: In vitro bacterial cultures (Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus agalactiae, Streptococcus dysgalactiae).
effective_dosage: Minimum inhibitory concentrations (MICs) ranged from 128 to 2048 μg/mL.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how cigarette-cannabis (CIG-CAN) co-use impacts changes in cigarette and other tobacco product (OTP) use during a smoking cessation attempt among Black adults.
results_summary: The study found that CIG-CAN users maintained higher OTP use and increased cannabis consumption over time, despite similar reductions in cigarettes per day (CPD) compared to non-cannabis users. There was no compensatory effect on cannabis use when CPD decreased, but OTP use showed a compensatory effect.
population_specificity: Black adults attempting to quit cigarette smoking (N=392).
study_duration: 18 weeks of pharmacotherapy, with follow-up through week 26.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Moroccan Cannabis sativa essential oil on peripheral neuropathic pain in mice.
results_summary: The essential oil significantly reduced pain sensitivity and improved functional and histological recovery over 21 days, with (E)-caryophyllene and α-humulene identified as the main active constituents.
population_specificity: Mice with induced peripheral neuropathic pain via sciatic nerve injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess how financial well-being influences cannabis consumption patterns, out-of-pocket costs, and symptom impact in cancer patients using medical cannabis.
results_summary: Patients reported significant symptom improvement, but those with financial struggles (NLC group) faced higher costs, used more THC-rich products, and often reduced or stopped use due to affordability. Both groups used cannabis daily and noted high symptom relief.
population_specificity: Cancer patients enrolled in the Minnesota Medical Cannabis Program.
study_duration: Survey conducted from December 2021 to January 2022 (intervention duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether a mobile phone-based intervention could successfully target perceived peer approval, perceptions of dangerousness, and negative effect expectancies related to driving after cannabis use (DACU) and whether changes in these variables would lead to changes in DACU.
results_summary: The study found that negative effect expectancies increased and perceived peer approval for DACU decreased from baseline to three-month follow-up, but these changes did not significantly mediate reductions in DACU instances. The intervention successfully targeted key variables associated with DACU.
population_specificity: 66 emerging adults who completed the mobile-based intervention and provided 3-month follow-up data.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore parent perspectives on the mental health impacts of cannabis use among youth and young adults (YYA).
results_summary: Parents reported that cannabis use worsened or triggered severe mental health crises in their children, increasing emotional and financial burdens. Many encountered healthcare providers who minimized cannabis-related risks, leading to inadequate support during treatment-seeking efforts.
population_specificity: Youth and young adults (YYA) who used cannabis and experienced mental health issues, as reported by their parents.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a mobile approach bias modification (ApBM) intervention targeting co-occurring alcohol and cannabis use among treatment-seeking adolescents.
results_summary: The study protocol describes an RCT to assess the ApBM intervention's impact on reducing problematic alcohol and cannabis use, with outcomes measured from pre-treatment through a three-month follow-up. The abstract does not provide specific results but outlines the planned methodology and expected implications.
population_specificity: Treatment-seeking adolescents with co-occurring alcohol and cannabis use.
study_duration: Outcomes measured from pre-treatment through a three-month follow-up (exact intervention duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of the CB2 receptor in mediating the analgesic effects of Cannabis sativa extract (CSE) in a rat model of neuropathic pain.
results_summary: CSE significantly reduced mechanical allodynia and thermal hyperalgesia and downregulated Iba1 and GFAP gene expression in neuropathic pain rats, effects that were blocked by the CB2 receptor antagonist AM630.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats with chronic constriction injury (CCI) of the sciatic nerve.
effective_dosage: 30 mg/kg CSE administered intraperitoneally once daily.
study_duration: 7 days (from day 7 to day 13 post-CCI surgery).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine daily associations between affect (positive/negative) and substance use (alcohol, cannabis, or concurrent use) and how these associations vary by sexual identity among women.
results_summary: Higher mean negative affect was associated with increased likelihood of cannabis use (but not alcohol or concurrent use) on a given day. Bisexual women were more likely than heterosexual women to report concurrent use days.
population_specificity: Women aged 18-35, including 88 lesbian, 84 bisexual, and 74 heterosexual participants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the neural encoding of subjective value for cannabis versus non-drug rewards in frequent cannabis users and assess the impact of cannabis and snack cues on this encoding.
results_summary: The study found that frequent cannabis users exhibited stronger neural value encoding for cannabis compared to snacks in brain regions associated with reward processing, suggesting disrupted non-drug reward valuation despite equivalent choice behavior.
population_specificity: 21 non-treatment-seeking people who use cannabis on a near-daily/daily frequency (≥4 days/week; 1 female).
effective_dosage: Not specified (participants chose between 0-6 cannabis puffs).
study_duration: Not specified (inpatient, crossover experiment with four conditions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the feasibility and effects of adjunctive medical cannabis in a residential substance use recovery program.
results_summary: Clients reported reduced drug cravings and improved management of pain and comorbid symptoms, while staff emphasized the importance of education and clear guidelines for successful program implementation. The program also helped destigmatize medical cannabis use.
population_specificity: Clients (n=14) and staff (n=7) in a residential substance use recovery program.
study_duration: Three months (with assessments at baseline, one month, and three months)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether preclinical findings of cannabis-induced immunosuppression translate to clinical settings, particularly in patients using immune checkpoint inhibitors (ICIs) for cancer therapy.
results_summary: The study found no meaningful changes in immune parameters (e.g., cytokines, T-cell counts, CRP) with cannabis use across multiple diseases, including autoimmune conditions. Cannabis did not appear to affect immune markers relevant to ICI function.
population_specificity: Patients with and without cancer, including those with autoimmune diseases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of mindfulness-based relapse prevention (MBRP) compared to treatment as usual (TAU) for reducing cannabis use in active users.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between MBRP and TAU groups on primary or secondary endpoints, though MBRP showed better treatment adherence and a slower increase in cannabis consumption over time. The MBRP protocol appeared at least as effective as TAU, with potentially more durable results, though not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Active cannabis users in France (40 participants total, 20 per group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of cannabis-based medicinal products (CBMPs) on patient-reported outcomes and adverse events in cancer pain patients.
results_summary: CBMPs were associated with statistically significant improvements in pain-specific measures, anxiety, sleep quality, and quality of life at 1, 3, and 6 months. Adverse events were mostly mild-to-moderate and reported by a small proportion of patients.
population_specificity: Cancer pain patients (n=168) from the UK Medical Cannabis Registry.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the perspectives and experiences of Irish neurologists regarding the use of cannabis-based medicines.
results_summary: The study found that neurologists in Ireland have average knowledge of cannabis-based medicines and are interested in their use, but the process for accessing these medicines is unclear. Educational programs on cannabinoid-based medicines are needed.
population_specificity: Irish neurologists (34 participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify neural features predictive of problem-level cannabis use and assess their generalizability across different populations.
results_summary: The study identified a neural network linked to problem cannabis use, which generalized to predict cannabis use in an independent adolescent sample and was associated with worse clinical outcomes in treatment-seeking adults. The network was specific to cannabis use and not alcohol use.
population_specificity: College students (n=191), European adolescents/emerging adults (n=1320), and adults seeking treatment for cannabis use disorder (n=33).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight diffuse alveolar hemorrhage (DAH) as a rare but severe complication associated with cannabis use.
results_summary: The study reported a case of acute respiratory failure and hemoptysis linked to cannabis use, demonstrating DAH as a potential serious respiratory complication. It emphasized the need for early intervention to prevent long-term complications like interstitial fibrosis and emphysema.
population_specificity: 34-year-old female with acute respiratory failure and hemoptysis.

study_goal: The researchers sought to determine whether N-acetylcysteine is effective in treating cannabis use disorder in youth when not paired with a robust behavioral treatment platform.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in cannabis abstinence or reduction between N-acetylcysteine and placebo groups, though both groups showed some reduction in cannabis use over time. Gastrointestinal adverse events were more common in the N-acetylcysteine group.
population_specificity: Treatment-seeking youth aged 14-21 with cannabis use disorder (N=192).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of buprenorphine versus naltrexone on cannabis use outcomes in individuals with Opioid Use Disorder (OUD).
results_summary: Participants receiving buprenorphine treatment were 39% less likely to use cannabis than those receiving naltrexone. No significant mediation was found between treatment assignment and cannabis use on opioid use outcomes or vice versa.
population_specificity: Treatment-seeking individuals with Opioid Use Disorder (OUD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of acute and chronic cannabis exposure on fear memory dynamics in a rodent model, focusing on its potential implications for PTSD treatment.
results_summary: Acute cannabis exposure impaired fear recall in females and prevented spontaneous recovery of fear in both sexes, while chronic exposure initially increased fear responses in females but showed no long-term differences. Acute exposure prior to extinction impaired extinction in females but enhanced it in males.
population_specificity: Male and female Sprague Dawley rats
study_duration: Acute (single exposure) and chronic (duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of medical marijuana versus prescription pain medications for chronic pain treatment using observational cohort data.
results_summary: At 3 months, 38.6% of medical marijuana users showed clinically meaningful improvements in pain, function, or global impression of change, with sustained response at 6 months. Medical marijuana was comparatively more effective than prescription medications (OR = 2.6), and opioid users saw a 39.3% decrease in morphine milligram equivalents.
population_specificity: 440 patients certified for medical marijuana by pain specialists and 8,114 patients treated with prescription pain medications in the same healthcare system.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the benefits and risks of cannabinoids in kidney health, particularly in individuals with pre-existing renal conditions, and to examine their therapeutic potential and adverse effects.
results_summary: The study found that cannabinoids may offer nephroprotection but also pose risks such as cannabinoid hyperemesis syndrome and acute kidney injury, with synthetic cannabinoids being particularly harmful. It also highlighted potential therapeutic roles of CB2 agonists and CB1 antagonists in kidney diseases and suggested cannabinoids might reduce kidney stone formation.
population_specificity: Individuals with pre-existing renal conditions, including diabetic nephropathy, chronic kidney disease, and obesity-related kidney dysfunction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) applied to the left dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (L-DLPFC) reduces cue-induced craving in individuals with cannabis use disorder (CUD).
results_summary: The study found that active rTMS significantly reduced cue-induced cannabis craving compared to sham treatment at the two-week follow-up, with moderate to large effect sizes observed. The effect diminished but remained notable at the four-week follow-up.
population_specificity: 71 treatment-seeking participants with moderate to severe cannabis use disorder (mean age 30.2, 37.5% female).
effective_dosage: 20 sessions of rTMS (10Hz, Beam-F3 targeting L-DLPFC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of a combined plant extract (CPE) formulation containing Cannabis sativa in alleviating long COVID symptoms.
results_summary: The CPE supplement showed a reduction in total symptom scores, particularly in moderate to severe fatigue and post-exertional malaise, but did not significantly reduce CRP levels. Adverse events were mostly mild and resolved by follow-up.
population_specificity: Participants with long COVID in Thailand.
effective_dosage: 4500 mg/day (combined plant extract, not Cannabis alone).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of drought stress and nanosilicon application on the morphological traits and essential oil content/composition of hemp (Cannabis sativa L.).
results_summary: The study found that nanosilicon improved morphological characteristics and altered essential oil content/composition under drought stress, with the highest cannabidiol content observed under severe water stress and 0.5 mM nanosilicon.
population_specificity: Four-week-old hemp (Cannabis sativa L.) seedlings.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of the cerebellum in drug reward, including Cannabis, by examining its neurological, molecular, and behavioral effects.
results_summary: The study highlights Cannabis's influence on the cerebellum through molecular signals, neurotransmitters, and synaptic transmission, but does not specify clinical outcomes or efficacy.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of existing research)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test whether cognitive bias modification (CBM) could reduce cannabis use and delinquent recidivism in young offenders.
results_summary: The study found that CBM reduced attentional bias for cannabis in both active- and sham-training groups but had no effect on actual cannabis use or delinquent recidivism at follow-up.
population_specificity: Young offenders in juvenile detention centers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the clinical features, epidemiology, pathophysiology, and management of cyclic vomiting syndrome (CVS) and cannabinoid hyperemesis syndrome (CHS), focusing on understanding their triggers, comorbidities, and treatment challenges.
results_summary: The study highlights that CHS presents a challenge due to difficulties in achieving sustained cannabis abstinence, while the benefits of other therapies for CHS remain poorly defined. It also notes that CVS treatment relies on antiemetics and antimigraine therapies, with prophylactic regimens involving neuromodulators and antiepileptics.
population_specificity: Adults and children with cyclic vomiting syndrome (CVS) and cannabinoid hyperemesis syndrome (CHS).

study_goal: The study does not specifically evaluate Cannabis; it focuses on dietary supplements excluding Cannabis.
results_summary: The study does not report any findings related to Cannabis, as it was explicitly excluded from the analysis.
population_specificity: Living kidney donors

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review current research on psychoactive substances, including Cannabis, focusing on analytical methods, environmental distribution, and ecological risk assessment, while identifying deficiencies and future research directions.
results_summary: The abstract highlights concerns about ecological risks of psychoactive substances like Cannabis due to their biological activity, but does not provide specific findings on human effects. It notes gaps in standardized analytical methods, toxicity data, and risk evaluation systems.
population_specificity: Not specified (environmental focus)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize published evidence on healthcare professionals' perspectives regarding the clinical use and relevance of medicinal cannabis (MC) for chronic pain.
results_summary: The review identified seven key themes, including MC as a treatment option for chronic pain, willingness to prescribe, legal issues, and concerns about safety, addiction, and adverse effects. Healthcare professionals highlighted the need for education and clinical guidelines to support evidence-based recommendations.
population_specificity: Healthcare professionals (physicians, nurses, pharmacists) from the United States, Israel, Canada, Australia, Ireland, and Norway.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether cannabinoid concentrations in blood, oral fluid, or breath could identify recent cannabis use within the past 3 hours, a period likely associated with the greatest impairment.
results_summary: The study found that frequent cannabis users had more residual THC in blood, and a 10 ng/mL THC cutoff in oral fluid showed the highest performance for detecting recent use within 3 hours, though it was still detectable in some participants up to 4.4 hours post-smoking. Cannabinol (CBN) in blood offered high specificity but low sensitivity, and behavioral assessment remains necessary to determine impairment.
population_specificity: 191 frequent (≥4/week) and occasional (<4/week) cannabis users.
effective_dosage: Participants smoked one cannabis cigarette (placebo [0.02%], or 5.9% or 13.4% THC) ad libitum.
study_duration: Samples were collected up to 6 hours after smoking.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety of concurrent use of Cannabis and warfarin, focusing on potential interactions and bleeding risks.
results_summary: The study found that Cannabis was among the substances reported to interact with warfarin, potentially increasing the risk of bleeding, including minor events like purpura and major events like intracranial bleeding.
population_specificity: Patients taking warfarin (specific demographics not detailed).
interactions: Increased risk of bleeding when used with warfarin.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a commercially available CBD-containing hemp oil extract on stress resilience, perceived recovery, mood, affect, body composition, and clinical safety markers in healthy human subjects.
results_summary: The study found that the CBD-containing hemp oil extract had effects on stress resilience, perceived recovery, mood, affect, and body composition, with clinical safety markers also assessed.
population_specificity: Healthy human subjects

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the utility, limitations, and impact of real-world evidence (RWE) in evaluating cannabis medicines and its role in complementing randomized controlled trial (RCT) data.
results_summary: The study found that RWE from diverse sources like registries, surveys, and digital health records can provide insights into cannabis medicine safety and effectiveness but cannot replace RCTs. While RWE may guide safety and adverse event monitoring, it lacks conclusive evidence on efficacy.
population_specificity: Not specified (global focus on diverse RWE initiatives)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the commercial Australian cannabis industry, summarize occupational health and safety hazards, and provide recommendations for worker safety.
results_summary: The review identified various occupational hazards in cannabis-related work environments, including exposure to organic dusts, bioaerosols, allergens, and psychoactive substances, but noted a lack of research on inhalable dust exposure and Australian-specific OHS guidance.
population_specificity: Workers in cannabis cultivation and manufacturing industries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to discuss potential toxicities of natural products (NPs), including herbal supplements, both alone and in combination with pharmaceutical agents.
results_summary: The abstract highlights concerns about toxicity and drug interactions with NPs but does not provide specific findings about Cannabis. It emphasizes that NPs can alter drug disposition and therapeutic effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion on natural products and dietary supplements)
interactions: Mentions potential interactions with pharmaceutical agents, enhancing or reducing therapeutic effects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the available evidence for Cannabis and other CAMs in treating inflammatory bowel diseases (IBDs).
results_summary: The abstract notes that few controlled studies exist on Cannabis for IBD, with limitations such as small sample sizes and lack of quality control for herbal preparations. It suggests CAMs like Cannabis may help ease symptoms but emphasizes the need for further research.
population_specificity: Patients with inflammatory bowel diseases (IBDs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review published data on the use of complementary and alternative medicine (CAM), including medical cannabis, in patients with psoriatic arthritis (PsA).
results_summary: The abstract mentions that herbal remedies, including medical cannabis, show promise but require more rigorous studies to evaluate their effectiveness. No specific results for cannabis are detailed.
population_specificity: Patients with psoriatic arthritis (PsA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of exercise as an adjunctive treatment for cannabis use disorder (CUD) by examining its effects on the endocannabinoid system and related psychobiological processes.
results_summary: The study suggests that exercise could help manage CUD by modulating the endocannabinoid system, reducing withdrawal symptoms, stress, and cravings, though specific efficacy data from trials are not provided. Chronic cannabis use may dysregulate the endocannabinoid system, affecting reward and stress responses.
population_specificity: Individuals diagnosed with cannabis use disorder (CUD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of cannabis-based treatments for symptoms related to multiple sclerosis (MS), including spasticity, pain, and urinary frequency.
results_summary: The study found that oral cannabis extract is effective in the short term for spasticity-related symptoms and pain but probably ineffective for objective spasticity improvement. Nabiximols oromucosal spray was probably effective for spasticity symptoms, pain, and urinary frequency but ineffective for objective spasticity outcomes and bladder incontinence.
population_specificity: Individuals with multiple sclerosis (MS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of canola oil with extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) on inflammatory markers and gastrointestinal symptoms in patients with ulcerative colitis (UC).
results_summary: The study found no significant improvements in inflammatory markers or gastrointestinal symptoms with canola oil consumption, unlike EVOO, which showed significant benefits.
population_specificity: 40 patients with ulcerative colitis (32 completed the study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of genistein supplementation with different dietary oils, including canola oil, in ameliorating oxidative and inflammatory status in rats with induced colitis.
results_summary: Canola oil, both pure and genistein-fortified, effectively reduced oxidative and inflammatory markers (MDA, MPO, IL-1β) in rats with colitis, though extra virgin olive oil showed slightly better results. Genistein delivered via oil was more effective than in aqueous solution.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley rats with acetic acid-induced colitis.
effective_dosage: 5 ml per kg body weight of canola oil (pure or genistein-fortified), administered orally.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of canola, sesame, and sesame-canola oils on cardio-metabolic biomarkers in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: The study did not report specific results for canola oil alone but indicated it would examine its effects on cardio-metabolic markers in adults with and without T2DM. The abstract suggests the study provides a foundation for future analysis of these effects.
population_specificity: 102 individuals with T2DM and their spouses.
effective_dosage: Not specified (regular dietary oil replaced with canola, sesame, or sesame-canola oils).
study_duration: Three 9-week phases separated by 4-week washout periods.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a novel method for detecting hydroperoxidized and epoxidized triacylglycerols (TAGs) in canola oil and margarine to assess lipid oxidation.
results_summary: The study found that refined canola oil contained higher concentrations of epoxidized TAGs (96.8 ± 2.08 μM) compared to hydroperoxidized TAGs (5.77 ± 0.04 μM). Margarine showed greater resistance to lipid oxidation, with minimal increases in epoxidized TAGs after heat treatment.
population_specificity: Not specified (food samples analyzed in vitro).
study_duration: Not applicable (single measurement, no intervention period).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of oxidized canola oil and tannic acid supplementation on nutrient digestibility and microbial metabolites in finishing pigs.
results_summary: Oxidized canola oil reduced nutrient digestibility and altered microbial metabolites, while tannic acid supplementation mitigated some negative effects of oxidized oil on microbial activity but also reduced nutrient digestibility.
population_specificity: Finishing pigs (initial body weight of 82.89 ± 2.26 kg)
effective_dosage: 5% fresh or oxidized canola oil (180 mEq/kg peroxide value), 0.1% tannic acid
interactions: Interactive effects between oxidized oil and tannic acid on microbial metabolites

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate liposomal formulations containing phytosterols and tocopherols from canola oil deodorizer distillate for use as functional food additives.
results_summary: The study successfully developed stable liposomes with high entrapment efficiency (>89%) for phytosterols and tocopherols, demonstrating adequate stability after pasteurization in model orange juice for a month.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro/model food system)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify the effects of canola oil on lipid parameters (TC, LDL, HDL, TG, Apo A1, Apo B) through a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: Canola oil consumption significantly reduced total cholesterol (-7.24 mg/dl) and LDL (-6.4 mg/dl) but had no effect on HDL, TG, Apo B, or Apo A1. Greater effects were observed in participants over 50 years and interventions longer than 30 days.
population_specificity: 1,359 participants across 27 trials (subgroup analysis for >50 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of electrocoagulation (EC) + electrooxidation (EO) and electrochemical peroxidation (ECP) processes in treating canola oil refinery wastewaters by measuring pollutant removal.
results_summary: The study found that EC alone effectively removed suspended and colloidal pollutants (over 90% TCOD and 80% TOC), while EC + EO achieved higher removal of dissolved pollutants (99% sCOD and 95% DOC). ECP showed moderate removal (77-86% sCOD and DOC).
population_specificity: Canola oil refinery wastewaters.
effective_dosage: Current densities between 0.91 and 13.66 mA cm-2, with optimized conditions at 7.61 mA cm-2 (TCOD) and 7.99 mA cm-2 (TOC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of canola oil, among other vegetable oils, on serum-mediated cholesterol efflux capacity and its association with central obesity in individuals at risk for or with metabolic syndrome.
results_summary: Canola oil increased serum-mediated cholesterol efflux capacity by 39% compared to baseline, similar to other tested oils. Central obesity was inversely associated with cholesterol efflux capacity.
population_specificity: Adults (n=101; mean age 49.5) at risk for or with metabolic syndrome.
effective_dosage: 60 g/day (incorporated into smoothies twice daily for a 3000-kcal diet).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the physical properties and oxidative stability of canola oil-based oleogels compared to grapeseed oil-based oleogels at varying wax concentrations.
results_summary: The study found that carnauba wax-based canola oil oleogels (CWO) showed better oxidative stability at high temperatures (60°C and 180°C) compared to control oils, while beeswax-based grapeseed oil oleogels (BWO) did not. CWO also exhibited stable solid-fat content across a temperature range (10-60°C), unlike BWO.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify an alternative vegetable oil to soybean oil for efficiently eliminating pesticide residues in ginseng extract while avoiding undesirable taste and odor.
results_summary: Canola oil performed best in organoleptic tests (no undesirable odor or taste) and showed no notable changes in ginsenosides after treatment, though soybean oil was more efficient in pesticide partitioning.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study with ginseng extract and vegetable oils).
effective_dosage: 1 mL of oil mixed with 20 mL of 10% aqueous ginseng extract and 7 mL of equivalent vegetable oil.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of canola oil (CO) and rice bran oil (RBO) on blood lipids in postmenopausal women with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Canola oil significantly reduced serum levels of triglycerides (TG), total cholesterol (TC), and LDL-C compared to the control group, though RBO showed greater improvements in these markers. HDL-C levels remained unchanged in all groups.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women with type 2 diabetes in Shiraz, Iran.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of different MUFA-rich and PUFA-rich oil blends, including canola oil variants, on the gut microbiota composition in individuals at risk of metabolic syndrome.
results_summary: The study found that MUFA-rich diets (including canola oil variants) elevated certain bacterial populations (e.g., Parabacteroides, Prevotella) while PUFA-rich diets favored others (e.g., Isobaculum). BMI was a predominant factor in gut microbiota composition, with MUFA-rich diets showing specific effects in obese subjects.
population_specificity: 25 volunteers with risk of metabolic syndrome (obese, overweight, or normal weight).
effective_dosage: 60 g per day of each oil blend.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of different dietary oils, including canola oil variants, on circulating PCSK9 levels and lipid profiles.
results_summary: CanolaDHA feeding resulted in the highest serum total cholesterol and LDL-cholesterol levels but the lowest plasma PCSK9 concentrations compared to other oils. PCSK9 levels correlated positively with serum TC, LDL-C, and apolipoproteins but not HDL-C.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract (likely general adult population based on context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether tocotrienol-enriched canola oil improves glycemic control, insulin sensitivity, and oxidative stress in individuals with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: Tocotrienol-enriched canola oil significantly reduced fasting blood sugar (FBS) and malondialdehyde (MDA) while increasing total antioxidant capacity (TAC) compared to pure canola oil, but it had no effect on insulin concentrations or HOMA-IR.
population_specificity: 50 patients aged 35-60 years with T2DM treated by noninsulin hypoglycemic drugs.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of including canola oil in the diet of dairy cows on milk production, composition, and the nutritional quality of milk fat for human consumption.
results_summary: The inclusion of 6% canola oil in cows' diets reduced milk yield and certain fatty acids (short-chain, medium-chain, saturated) but significantly improved the nutritional profile by increasing long-chain, unsaturated, monounsaturated, and polyunsaturated fatty acids, omega-3, rumenic acid, oleic acid, and the h/H milk index.
population_specificity: Eighteen Holstein cows in the middle stage of lactation with an average daily milk yield of 22 (±4) kg/d.
effective_dosage: 3% and 6% inclusion of canola oil in the diet (dry matter basis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the antioxidant effects and thermal stability of Tarom Mahali rice bran extracts in canola oil during frying, evaluating its potential as a natural alternative to synthetic antioxidants like TBHQ.
results_summary: The ethanol:water (50:50) ultrasonic extract showed the highest antioxidant activity and thermal stability in canola oil, with 800 ppm of the extract performing better than 100 ppm TBHQ in inhibiting lipid oxidation during frying.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study on canola oil)
effective_dosage: 100, 800, and 1200 ppm of Tarom Mahali rice bran extract

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of high-oleic acid canola oil (HOCO)-DHA, alone and combined with barley β-glucan, on managing cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk factors in individuals with metabolic syndrome (MetS).
results_summary: The study tested novel food combinations containing HOCO-DHA and barley β-glucan for their potential to improve CVD risk factors, including blood lipid profile, inflammatory status, and body composition, but specific results were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Adults with metabolic syndrome (n=35).
effective_dosage: 50 g/day of HOCO-DHA (with 3 g/day of DHA in one treatment arm).
study_duration: Four 28-day treatment phases separated by 4-week washout intervals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of different dietary oils, including canola oil variants, on inflammatory biomarkers and gene expression in individuals with abdominal obesity and metabolic syndrome.
results_summary: DHA-enriched canola oil (CanolaDHA) increased plasma adiponectin and reduced IL1B expression compared to other oils, while conventional canola oil (Canola) lowered high-sensitivity C-reactive protein levels compared to flax/safflower oil.
population_specificity: 114 adult men and women with abdominal obesity and at least one other criterion for metabolic syndrome.
study_duration: 4 weeks per diet, with 4-week washout periods between diets.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how varying dietary levels of Crude Degummed Canola Oil (CDCO) affect plasma metabolite profiles in grazing primiparous Holstein-Friesian cows.
results_summary: CDCO supplementation influenced BHBA levels but had no significant effect on plasma NEFA, cholesterol, or glucose metabolites. The duration of supplementation had a greater impact on plasma metabolites than the dosage levels.
population_specificity: Primiparous Holstein-Friesian cows grazing high-quality pastures during spring, 40 days in milk.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of varying oleic, linoleic, and docosahexaenoic acid consumption on human LDL-proteoglycan binding in a subset of participants from the Canola Oil Multi-center Intervention Trial (COMIT).
results_summary: High-oleic canola oil lowered LDL-proteoglycan binding relative to baseline and performed better than corn/safflower oil and DHA-enriched high oleic canola oil, despite increasing cholesteryl oleate percentage in LDL. The study suggests that high-oleic canola oil does not raise LDL-proteoglycan binding, contrary to some animal model findings.
population_specificity: 50 participants from the COMIT trial exhibiting good compliance.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of daily intake of 200 mg tocotrienols (T3) added to canola oil on microalbuminuria, inflammation, and nitrosative stress in type 2 diabetic patients.
results_summary: The study found that T3-enriched canola oil significantly reduced urine microalbumin and serum hs-CRP levels in diabetic patients, indicating potential kidney protection and anti-inflammatory effects. No significant changes were observed in urine volume, creatinine levels, or serum nitric oxide levels.
population_specificity: 50 patients with type 2 diabetes (FBS >126 mg/dl) treated with non-insulin hypoglycemic drugs.
effective_dosage: 15 ml T3-enriched canola oil (200 mg/day T3).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the combined effect of a canola oil-enriched low-glycemic-load diet on glycemic control and cardiovascular disease risk factors in individuals with type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: The canola oil-enriched diet resulted in a greater reduction in HbA1c levels compared to the control diet, particularly in participants with higher systolic blood pressure. It also showed greater reductions in cardiovascular disease risk scores, while the control diet improved vascular reactivity.
population_specificity: 141 participants with type 2 diabetes (HbA1c 6.5%-8.5%) treated with oral antihyperglycemic agents.
effective_dosage: 31 g canola oil per 2,000 kcal, provided as a bread supplement.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of varying fatty acid compositions (n-9, n-6, and n-3) in canola oil and other oils on markers of coronary heart disease (CHD) risk.
results_summary: CanolaDHA (DHA-rich canola oil) significantly improved HDL cholesterol, reduced triglycerides and systolic blood pressure, and lowered Framingham 10-y CHD risk scores compared to other oils. All diets reduced total and LDL cholesterol, but CanolaDHA showed the most comprehensive benefits.
population_specificity: Volunteers with abdominal obesity.
study_duration: Each treatment period lasted 4 weeks, separated by 4-week washout intervals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate how microwave heating affects the quality of canola oil (CO) when blended with oxidative-stable palm olein (PO).
results_summary: Microwave heating increased degradation markers in CO, but blending with PO slowed oxidative deterioration. PO addition reduced primary and secondary oxidation products in CO, though it did not significantly affect free fatty acid or polymer formation.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study on oil samples).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of diets enriched with different oils, including canola oil, on cardiovascular disease risk factors in individuals with abdominal obesity.
results_summary: The study demonstrated excellent dietary adherence, with plasma DHA concentrations increasing by over 100% in the DHA-enriched phase. The study was sufficiently powered to detect small differences in outcomes, suggesting potential benefits of specific oil blends on CVD risk factors.
population_specificity: Individuals with abdominal obesity (waist circumference ≥90 cm for males, ≥84 cm for females) and at least one additional CVD risk factor.
effective_dosage: Not specified (weight-maintaining diets with oil-blended shakes provided).
study_duration: Five 30-day dietary phases separated by four-week washout periods.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of maternal dietary canola oil on the susceptibility of female rat offspring to mammary carcinogenesis.
results_summary: Offspring of canola-fed dams showed significantly decreased tumor multiplicity and volume, along with increased survival rate, suggesting a potential anticancer effect of maternal dietary canola oil. The mRNA expression of gamma-glutamyltransferase 1 was also higher in the canola group.
population_specificity: Female Sprague-Dawley rat offspring
effective_dosage: 10% canola oil as a fat source in the diet

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether infant formulas containing canola oil support normal infant growth as assessed by weight and length gain.
results_summary: The study found no differences in weight or length gain between infants fed formulas with or without canola oil, indicating that canola oil supports normal growth. These results were consistent across multiple measurement periods and longitudinal analyses.
population_specificity: Full-term infants in the German Infant Nutritional Intervention study (GINI).
study_duration: From week 4 to month 7 of life

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the biological effects of a functional oil enriched with phytosterols in MCTs and high-oleic canola oil versus olive oil on lipid profiles in overweight, hyperlipidemic men.
results_summary: The functional oil group showed significant reductions in total cholesterol and LDL-C compared to the olive oil group, with no changes in HDL-C. Both groups experienced similar decreases in body weight and triacylglycerol levels.
population_specificity: Overweight, hyperlipidemic men

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if canola oil intake, with or without salt loading, affects antioxidant and oxidative stress markers and aortic gene expression in hypertensive rats.
results_summary: Canola oil reduced antioxidant enzyme activity and increased plasma lipids, suggesting potential cardiovascular risks. Salt loading with canola oil further increased oxidative stress markers and decreased aortic gene expression of antioxidant-related enzymes.
population_specificity: Male stroke-prone spontaneously hypertensive (SHRSP) rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a single dose of canola oil versus MCT oil on post-ingestion plasma triglyceride levels in healthy men.
results_summary: Canola oil ingestion led to a 47% increase in mean triglyceride levels above baseline, while MCT oil decreased levels by 15%. The results were statistically significant (p <0.001).
population_specificity: 20 healthy men
study_duration: Single-dose intervention with measurements up to 5 hours post-ingestion

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of feeding or infusing canola oil on rumen fermentation, nutrient digestibility, duodenal fatty acid flows, and milk composition in late-lactation Holstein cows.
results_summary: Feeding canola oil increased duodenal flows and milk concentrations of beneficial fatty acids (e.g., CLA) without affecting nutrient digestibility, while abomasal infusion reduced feed intake, nutrient digestion, and milk fat yield. Both methods reduced saturated fats and increased unsaturated C18 fats in milk.
population_specificity: Late-lactation Holstein cows with ruminal and duodenal cannulas.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the type of dietary fat (specifically canola oil vs. beef fat) influences fat storage and whether voluntary exercise could prevent diet-induced obesity in mice.
results_summary: Mice fed canola oil had significantly less body fat (16.8 g/100 g body weight) compared to those fed beef fat (23.2 g/100 g body weight). Voluntary exercise further reduced body fat in all diet groups, including canola oil (9.6 g/100 g body weight).
population_specificity: 6-week-old female mice
effective_dosage: 40.8% of energy from fat (canola oil diet)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of canola oil as a dust control method in improving indoor air quality and reducing acute health effects in swine barns.
results_summary: The study found that canola oil significantly reduced inhalable dust and endotoxin levels compared to traditional methods, leading to fewer acute health effects such as lung function decline and inflammatory responses in subjects.
population_specificity: Twenty lifetime nonsmoking males with no allergy, asthma, or prior swine barn exposure.
effective_dosage: Not specified (applied as a dust control sprinkling method).

study_goal: To compare the metabolic effects of a lipid-lowering diet containing canola oil versus olive oil in hyperlipidemic patients.
results_summary: Both canola oil and olive oil diets similarly reduced total serum cholesterol, LDL cholesterol, and improved glucose tolerance, with a slightly greater LDL reduction in the canola oil group (-17% vs. -13%).
population_specificity: Hyperlipidemic patients (n=22).
effective_dosage: Not specified (food prepared daily based on individual energy requirements).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of canola oil on platelet function and fatty acid composition in healthy male subjects compared to a baseline diet and safflower oil.
results_summary: Canola oil reduced arachidonic acid in platelet phospholipids by 35% and increased long-chain n-3 fatty acids by 7-26%. It lowered platelet aggregation at 3 weeks and reduced ATP secretion at 8 weeks, showing longer-lasting effects on platelet function compared to safflower oil.
population_specificity: 30 healthy male subjects

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of dietary canola oil level and quality (oxidized vs. non-oxidized) on exocrine pancreatic secretions in pigs.
results_summary: The study found that replacing starch with canola oil decreased alpha-amylase secretion and increased lipase secretion. Oxidized canola oil further increased total lipase activities, indicating pancreatic adaptation to dietary lipid variations.
population_specificity: Four barrows (pigs) with an average initial weight of 35 kg.
effective_dosage: 15% canola oil in the diet, fed twice daily (900 g per meal).
study_duration: Each experimental period included a 7-day adaptation followed by 4 days of pancreatic juice collection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of dietary canola oil (10% and 20% inclusion) on fatty acid composition and lipid oxidation in pig muscles.
results_summary: Canola oil increased unsaturated and polyunsaturated fatty acids in muscle lipids but had no significant effect on microsomal enzymic lipid peroxidation, heme pigment, nonheme iron, or total lipid concentration. Lipid oxidation in stored muscle samples tended to be higher with canola oil, likely due to increased polyunsaturated fatty acids.
population_specificity: Pigs at approximately 35 days of age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of an omega 3-6-9 supplement versus a canola oil placebo on caregiver-reported behavior and sleep in toddlers born extremely preterm exhibiting ASD-like symptoms.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between the omega 3-6-9 group and the canola oil placebo group in caregiver-reported behavior or sleep outcomes, suggesting canola oil did not outperform the active supplement. Results were preliminary and require replication in a larger sample.
population_specificity: Toddlers aged 18-38 months born at ≤29 weeks' gestation exhibiting symptoms commonly seen with ASD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of vitamin D-fortified canola oil versus vitamin D supplementation on serum vitamin D levels and bone turnover markers.
results_summary: Vitamin D-fortified canola oil and supplements both increased serum vitamin D levels, particularly in vitamin D-sufficient individuals, but had no significant effect on bone turnover markers.
population_specificity: 93 healthy participants aged 18-30 years.
effective_dosage: 25 g canola oil daily, fortified with 1000 IU vitamin D.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether genetic variations influence the responsiveness of blood lipids to DHA supplementation in high-oleic canola oil (HOCO) in individuals with metabolic syndrome.
results_summary: HOCO-DHA reduced blood TAG concentrations by 24% compared to HOCO alone, with no significant influence from genetic variations in the studied genes. The TAG-lowering effect was consistent across participants, showing lower interindividual variability than other studies.
population_specificity: 129 subjects with metabolic syndrome
effective_dosage: 1 to 2.5 g/day of DHA (supplemented in HOCO)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of dietary capsaicin on interscapular brown adipose tissue (BAT) and adjacent white adipose tissue (WAT) using spatial metabolomics.
results_summary: Capsaicin induced similar metabolite alterations across various regions of BAT and significantly influenced metabolites in adjacent WAT, with changes linked to thermogenesis, glycerol phospholipid metabolism, and the pentose phosphate pathway.
population_specificity: Not specified (animal or human study not explicitly stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of daily supplementation with rapeseed/canola oil versus olive oil on serum lipids, liver enzymes, and inflammatory gene expression in obese men.
results_summary: Canola oil improved serum lipids (reduced total and LDL cholesterol), liver enzymes, and basal inflammation in adipose tissue but triggered an acute pro-inflammatory response after a meal. Olive oil showed similar effects for monocyte chemoattractant protein-1 (CCL2) but did not reduce IL6 expression like canola oil.
population_specificity: Obese men

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary supplementation with canola oil (as a placebo) had any effect on plasma concentration, multimer distribution, and collagen binding activity of von Willebrand factor (vWF) in subjects with mild hypertension.
results_summary: The study found that canola oil, used as a placebo, did not significantly alter vWF concentration or function in hypertensive or normotensive subjects. No adverse effects or benefits were reported specifically for canola oil.
population_specificity: Subjects with mild hypertension and normotensive individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects of canola oil as a placebo compared to an Omega-3-6-9 supplement on parent-reported ASD symptoms and related behaviors in toddlers born very preterm.
results_summary: The study found no significant improvements in ASD symptoms or related behaviors for children assigned to canola oil, with effects confined to one subscale in the treatment group. Canola oil served as a placebo and showed no notable benefits or adverse effects.
population_specificity: Toddlers aged 18-38 months born at ≤29 weeks of gestation exhibiting early signs of ASD.
effective_dosage: Canola oil containing 124 mg palmitic acid, 39 mg stearic acid, 513 mg linoleic acid, 225 mg α-linolenic acid, and 1346 mg oleic acid, administered daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of topical capsaicin 8% on pain, neurotoxicity, and mood in patients with chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy (CIPN).
results_summary: Capsaicin 8% significantly reduced pain intensity and improved neurotoxicity symptoms in 53% of patients, with marginal mood changes. However, the effect was marked by an "on-off" pattern, and quantitative sensory testing did not support nerve degeneration concerns.
population_specificity: 17 patients with painful CIPN.
study_duration: Data collected at baseline, directly after treatment, and at 2 and 8 weeks post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the influence of topiramate on capsaicin-induced mast cell degranulation and CGRP release from the dura mater in a rat model to understand migraine pathophysiology.
results_summary: Capsaicin significantly increased mast cell degranulation in both female and male rats, but systemic topiramate treatment for 10 days prevented this effect. Topiramate applied in situ did not protect against capsaicin-induced degranulation but reduced CGRP release.
population_specificity: Rats (both sexes)
effective_dosage: Capsaicin (10-3 M), topiramate (10-3 M, 20 µL in situ; 20 mg/kg/day for 10 days systemically)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of capsaicin and menthol in alleviating abdominal pain in IBS patients, focusing on their roles in modulating TRPV1 and TRPM8 receptors.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that capsaicin's effect on relieving abdominal pain in IBS patients was not statistically significant, though two long-term intervention studies suggested its potential to reduce visceral hypersensitivity and subsequently alleviate pain.
population_specificity: IBS patients with abdominal pain.
study_duration: Not specified (long-term intervention mentioned in two studies)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of capsaicin on mesothelioma cells, including its antiproliferative properties and potential to reduce cisplatin resistance.
results_summary: Capsaicin significantly reduced proliferation of both parental and cisplatin-resistant mesothelioma cells, promoted S-phase cell cycle arrest, inhibited migration, and suppressed AKT and ERK1/2 activation.
population_specificity: Mesothelioma cells (MSTO-211H and NCI-H2052), representing major mesothelioma subtypes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of topical capsaicin in treating neuropathic pain, knee osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis, and painful osteotendinous syndromes.
results_summary: Capsaicin 8% is recommended as a second-choice medication for neuropathic pain with high evidence, and it shows good evidence for knee osteoarthritis and rheumatoid arthritis. However, its use in painful osteotendinous syndromes lacks supporting studies, warranting caution.
population_specificity: Patients with neuropathic pain, knee osteoarthritis, rheumatoid arthritis, and painful osteotendinous syndromes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of cryotherapy in reducing burning pain induced by capsaicin (8%) patches (QUTENZA) in a neuropathic pain cohort and to assess subsequent neuropathic pain during an 8-week follow-up.
results_summary: Cryotherapy significantly reduced burning pain VAS scores at 60 minutes post-application but had no effect on neuropathic pain scores over the 8-week follow-up period.
population_specificity: 99 patients with neuropathic pain (80% women in the cryotherapy group, 69% women in the no cryotherapy group; median ages 51 and 48, respectively).
study_duration: Immediate effects measured at 30 and 60 minutes; follow-up lasted 8 weeks.

study_goal: To investigate the benefits of topical 8% capsaicin patches for reducing postsurgical neuropathic pain level and area.
results_summary: The pooled analysis showed a significant reduction in neuropathic pain (Cohen's d = 1.09, p < 0.001), with all studies reporting decreased pain area and some indicating continued reduction with repeated application.
population_specificity: Patients with postsurgical neuropathic pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the antitumor mechanism of Capsaicin in hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) cells, focusing on its effects via the c-Myc/MCT4 signaling pathway.
results_summary: Capsaicin demonstrated cytotoxic and apoptotic effects in HCC cells, reducing glycolysis-related proteins (HK2, PKM2, LDHA, Glut1, c-Myc, MCT4) and metabolic outputs (glucose, lactate, ATP). It also suppressed tumor growth in a mouse xenograft model without adverse effects on body weight or organ health.
population_specificity: Hep3B and Huh7 hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) cells, and BALB/c nude mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether TRPV1 activation by capsaicin could enhance the skin barrier function by reducing inflammatory cytokine release and promoting tight junction development in keratinocytes under inflammatory conditions.
results_summary: Capsaicin pre-treatment initially reduced CLDN1 gene expression but later increased CLDN1 protein levels significantly compared to TNFα-only treated cells, while also reducing IL-8 cytokine release. These findings suggest capsaicin may enhance skin barrier repair under inflammation.
population_specificity: In vitro model using HaCaT keratinocyte cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of capsaicin as a treatment for non-allergic rhinitis (NAR) by analyzing its impact on nasal symptoms and therapeutic response.
results_summary: Meta-analysis showed significant improvements in total nasal symptom scores (TNSS) and visual analog scale (VAS) scores, along with a higher proportion of therapeutic responders in capsaicin-treated patients compared to placebo. Some studies also noted reductions in substance P levels and TRPV1 expression post-treatment.
population_specificity: Patients with non-allergic rhinitis (NAR).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the role of capsaicin in cancer therapy, particularly through its interaction with the TRPV1 channel, and its effects on cancer cell death, pain mediation, and chemo-sensitivity.
results_summary: The study found that capsaicin, via TRPV1 activation, influences cancer processes through calcium influx, affecting cell signaling linked to growth and death, and is implicated in cancer-induced pain and chemo-sensitivity. It highlights capsaicin's potential as a therapeutic target but also discusses its limitations.
population_specificity: Not specified (general cancer biology context)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an HA-Mn-CAP Gel could enhance CAR-T cell therapy efficacy by targeting CD44 and TRPV1 receptors, relieving tumor hypoxia, and increasing ligand expression in melanoma.
results_summary: HA-Mn-CAP Gel increased NKG2D ligand expression >2.7 times on melanoma cells and improved tumor inhibition by 1.5 times when combined with NKG2D/CAR-T therapy. It also enhanced T-cell proliferation and infiltration, particularly CD8+ cells.
population_specificity: A375 melanoma cells and melanoma-bearing NSG mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine capsaicin's cytotoxic and anti-cancer effects in the lung cancer cell line (A549).
results_summary: Capsaicin significantly reduced lung cancer cell viability, induced apoptosis, downregulated TGF-β and SMAD2, and inhibited cell migration. The IC-50 was measured at 101.2μM/ml.
population_specificity: Lung cancer cell line (A549)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of capsaicin on atherosclerosis progression, focusing on lipid metabolism, foam cell formation, and inflammatory responses.
results_summary: Capsaicin reduced weight gain, visceral adiposity, blood triglycerides, total and non-HDL cholesterol, and atherosclerotic lesions. It also improved hepatic oxidative and inflammatory status, reduced systemic inflammation, and decreased foam cell formation by modulating cholesterol influx and efflux via TRPV1 activation.
population_specificity: Apolipoprotein E knockout mice and C57BL/6 controls

study_goal: The researchers aimed to predict the effect of capsaicin from pepper as a pancreatic lipase inhibitor using computational approaches to assess its potential for obesity management.
results_summary: Computational analysis identified capsaicin as a potential pancreatic lipase inhibitor with a binding energy of -7.7 kcal/mol, interacting with key residues (Ser-152 and His-263) at the substrate binding site, suggesting anti-obesity potential.
population_specificity: Not specified (computational study, no human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anticancer properties of capsaicin on oral cancer cells through in vitro investigations, focusing on its effects on cell viability, apoptosis, and gene expression.
results_summary: Capsaicin significantly reduced cell viability in oral cancer cells (IC50 of 74.4 μM/mL), induced apoptosis (evidenced by chromatin condensation and nuclear disintegration), and inhibited cell migration. Gene expression analysis showed downregulation of TNFα and NFκB.
population_specificity: Oral cancer cells (KB1 cell line) in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of high-concentration capsaicin patches (179 mg) in alleviating neuropathic pain and associated symptoms in breast cancer patients with chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy (CIPN).
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in neuropathic pain scores and pain intensity, with progressive improvements over time, particularly in patients receiving multiple treatments. Patients also reported significant improvements in CIPN-related quality of life, with adverse reactions mainly limited to application site reactions.
population_specificity: Female breast cancer patients with painful CIPN following neoadjuvant/adjuvant therapy (median age 61 years).
effective_dosage: 179 mg capsaicin patch, up to three treatments over 36 weeks.
study_duration: 36 weeks with follow-up visits every 12 weeks or upon retreatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the de-functionalization and temporal functional recovery of C-nociceptor evoked pain after topical 8% capsaicin application over 4 consecutive days.
results_summary: Capsaicin abolished heat pain but did not completely eliminate sensation to electrical stimulation. Recovery times varied between nociceptor subtypes, with full sensory recovery occurring within 7 weeks in healthy subjects. Axon reflex flare recovery remained incomplete even after 49 days.
population_specificity: Human forearm skin (n=14)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate capsaicin's anti-cancer activity, particularly in gynecological cancers, and explore strategies to overcome its poor bioavailability and side effects.
results_summary: Capsaicin demonstrated growth-suppressive and chemosensitizing effects in cervical and ovarian cancers in vitro and in vivo, but its clinical use is limited by poor bioavailability and adverse gastrointestinal effects. Encapsulation and non-pungent analogs were investigated to mitigate these drawbacks.
population_specificity: Human cancer cells (in vitro) and mouse models (in vivo), specifically cervical and ovarian cancers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether capsaicin could mitigate age-related declines in oral defensin levels and modulate immune responses in oral tissues.
results_summary: Aging did not uniformly reduce defensin levels, but capsaicin treatment increased defensin levels in some cases, potentially via TRPV1-mediated pathways, suggesting it may counteract age-related declines in oral immune function.
population_specificity: Young and aged mice, and senescence-induced human oral keratinocytes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the protective effects of capsaicin on liver diseases, including liver injury, NAFLD, liver fibrosis, and liver cancer, by reviewing its molecular mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found that capsaicin exerts protective effects on liver diseases through anti-oxidant, anti-inflammatory, anti-steatosis, and anti-fibrosis mechanisms. These effects are attributed to its role as a TRPV1 agonist.
population_specificity: Individuals with liver diseases, including NAFLD, NASH, cirrhosis, and liver cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize recent evidence on the use of capsaicin, particularly high-concentration patches, for managing cancer-related neuropathic pain.
results_summary: The study found that capsaicin is endorsed by international guidelines for treating chronic painful chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy, with emerging data suggesting better tolerability and faster analgesia compared to systemic treatments. However, randomized controlled trial data specific to cancer pain are limited.
population_specificity: Cancer survivors with chronic pain, particularly those with chemotherapy-induced peripheral neuropathy.
effective_dosage: High-concentration capsaicin patches (specific dosage not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether capsaicin (CAP) combined with cisplatin (DDP) could inhibit epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) and migration in tongue squamous cell carcinoma (TSCC) cells.
results_summary: CAP combined with DDP inhibited both non-TGF-β1-induced and TGF-β1-induced EMT and migration in TSCC cells, mediated by the AMPK/mTOR and Claudin-1/PI3K/AKT/mTOR pathways, respectively. In vivo validation using a nude lung metastasis mouse model supported the hypothesis that CAP and DDP combination inhibits TSCC metastasis.
population_specificity: Tongue squamous cell carcinoma (TSCC) cells and a nude lung metastasis mouse model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether preoperative systemic capsaicin could reduce tooth sensitivity (TS) after in-office bleaching procedures.
results_summary: Capsaicin showed a significant increase in tooth bleaching sensitivity (TBS) immediately post-bleaching but a decrease by 24 hours, though the placebo group exhibited milder TS overall. The study concluded that capsaicin did not significantly affect TS post-bleaching.
population_specificity: 30 participants undergoing in-office tooth bleaching.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether capsaicin (CAP) and cisplatin (DDP) have a synergistic antitumor effect on tongue squamous cell carcinoma (TSCC) cells and to explore the underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: CAP reduced TSCC cell activity dose- and time-dependently, induced mitochondrial apoptosis, and showed synergistic cytotoxic effects when combined with DDP. The combination activated the TRPV1 receptor, causing Ca2+ overload and calpain pathway activation, leading to mitochondrial apoptosis.
population_specificity: Tongue squamous cell carcinoma (TSCC) cells and xenograft models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the potential anti-obesity effects of capsaicin and orange peel extract, focusing on their thermogenic, metabolic, and anti-inflammatory properties.
results_summary: Capsaicin was found to suppress adipogenesis and induce apoptosis in preadipocytes and adipocytes, while citrus polyphenols from orange peel extract reduced adipocyte development and cellular lipid content, suggesting anti-obesity benefits.
population_specificity: Not specified (general obesity-related mechanisms discussed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether capsaicin could prevent diabetic myocardial infarction-induced injury by inhibiting ferroptosis through activation of the TRPV1 and Nrf2/HMOX1 signaling pathway.
results_summary: Capsaicin treatment inhibited ferroptosis, improved post-MI cardiac function, and reduced myocardial inflammation and fibrosis in diabetic mice. The mechanism involved activation of TRPV1, upregulation of Nrf2 expression, and increased HMOX1 levels.
population_specificity: Type 2 diabetic mice with induced myocardial infarction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the neuronal pathways and pharmacological mechanisms of capsaicin in managing chronic neuropathic pain, including its effects on the CNS and PNS.
results_summary: The study found that capsaicin induces analgesia through TRPV1-mediated calcium ion influx, leading to axonal ablation and functional defunctionalisation in the PNS, with evidence of CNS modulation in chronic neuropathic pain conditions. Further research, including fMRI studies, was suggested to explore long-term CNS effects.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic neuropathic pain, including chronic post-surgical pain, phantom limb pain, and cluster headaches.

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine the impact and treatment considerations of high injection lesions of the hand, including the role of the chemical nature of the substance involved.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that high injection lesions of the hand are serious and often underestimated, with both physical and chemical factors influencing treatment. No specific findings about Capsaicin are mentioned.
population_specificity: Not specified (abstract refers to high injection lesions of the hand generally).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficiency and tolerance of four nebulization delivery methods for capsaicin in cats, assessing cough response as a measurable outcome.
results_summary: The face mask (FM) method was the most efficient for capsaicin nebulization, inducing the highest number of positive cough responses and requiring the lowest concentration of capsaicin. The plexiglass chamber (PC) was best tolerated but less efficient, while the Elizabethan collar (EC) had low efficiency and compliance.
population_specificity: Cats
effective_dosage: Capsaicin concentrations ranging from 91.8 ± 157.2 µM (FM) to 350.0 ± 225.7 µM (EC)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the efficacy and mechanism of traditionally made kochujang with varying capsaicin levels in alleviating memory impairment in rats with scopolamine-induced amnesia.
results_summary: Kochujang, particularly with medium capsaicin levels (1.2 mg%), improved memory function, reduced hippocampal cell death, and positively influenced gut microbiota and short-chain fatty acid levels, comparable to the positive control (donepezil). The medium-CPS group showed the most significant impact on cognitive health and gut-brain axis interactions.
population_specificity: Sprague-Dawley male rats with scopolamine-induced memory impairment.
effective_dosage: 1 % kochujang in a 43-energy% high-fat diet, with capsaicin levels of 0.5 mg% (Low-CPS), 1.2 mg% (Medium-CPS), and 1.7 mg% (High-CPS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether capsaicin attenuates salt-induced hypertension via the AMPK/Akt/Nrf2 pathway in the hypothalamic paraventricular nucleus (PVN).
results_summary: Capsaicin pretreatment slowed blood pressure elevation and heart rate, improved cardiac hypertrophy, reduced proinflammatory markers, and modulated the AMPK/Akt/iNOS pathway in hypertensive rats.
population_specificity: Dahl salt-sensitive (Dahl S) rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the molecular features and biological activities of Nitro dihydrocapsaicin (NDHC) and Capsaicin (CAP) in human corneal epithelial cells, focusing on antioxidant and anti-inflammatory effects.
results_summary: NDHC showed lower cytotoxicity, maintained cell viability and shape, and prevented oxidative stress and inflammation in HCE cells compared to CAP. NDHC may serve as an alternative anti-inflammatory agent targeting TRPV1 for hyperosmotic stress-induced ocular surface damage.
population_specificity: Human corneal epithelial (HCE) cells

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a novel CAP/BSA@TCP-ZIF-8 nanoparticle drug carrier system could enhance calcium overload therapy in tumors by activating TRPV1 channels and providing exogenous Ca2+ to induce apoptosis.
results_summary: The study found that the nanomaterial effectively activated TRPV1 channels and provided exogenous Ca2+, leading to Ca2+ overload and apoptosis in tumor cells, demonstrating anti-tumor effects in both in vivo and in vitro experiments.
population_specificity: Tumor cells (in vitro and in vivo models).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of a multifunctional nanocarrier for co-delivering capsaicin and nitrogen-doped graphene quantum dots to enhance cancer therapy and cellular imaging.
results_summary: The optimized nanoparticles demonstrated significant toxicity against human breast adenocarcinoma cells (MCF-7) and showed strong cellular uptake, confirmed by fluorescent signals. The nanocarrier achieved a high loading capacity for capsaicin (70.80 ± 0.05%) and desirable nanoparticle properties.
population_specificity: Human breast adenocarcinoma cell line (MCF-7)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the histological and biochemical effects of capsaicin on implant osseointegration and oxidative stress in rats.
results_summary: Capsaicin showed no positive effect on osteointegration but had a significant positive effect on oxidative stress, with higher doses yielding better antioxidant status. The control group exhibited higher oxidative stress compared to capsaicin-treated groups.
population_specificity: Male Wistar albino rats weighing 250-300 g.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to critically evaluate the efficacy and safety of topical capsaicin in reducing pain in osteoarthritis (OA) patients.
results_summary: Meta-analysis of eight RCTs showed that topical capsaicin (0.0125%-5%) may reduce OA pain severity compared to placebo, but it increased the risk of burning sensations at the application site. Limitations included short study durations, small sample sizes, and high heterogeneity.
population_specificity: Osteoarthritis patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how capsaicin influences LPS-induced pro-inflammatory macrophage phenotypes and its immunomodulatory effects via TRPV1 activation.
results_summary: Capsaicin activation of TRPV1 led to distinct macrophage responses, with LPS pre-treatment followed by capsaicin causing increased calcium influx and a shift toward an anti-inflammatory M2b-like polarization state. The study also assessed functional capacity by infecting macrophages with Leishmania mexicana.
population_specificity: J774 macrophage cell line and bone marrow-derived macrophages

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-metastasis activity of Capsaicin (CAP) in combination with cisplatin (DDP) in nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC).
results_summary: CAP alone and in combination with DDP showed synergistic cytotoxic effects on NPC cells, inhibited migration and invasion, and upregulated SERPINB2 expression, which was linked to inhibiting epithelial-mesenchymal transition (EMT) and ERK signaling.
population_specificity: Nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC) cell lines and tissues, with implications for head and neck squamous cell carcinoma.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate capsaicin's ability to counteract neurotoxicity in vitro and cognitive impairments, mitochondrial deficits, and oxidative stress in a rodent model of Huntington's disease.
results_summary: Capsaicin demonstrated neuroprotective effects in N2a cells and improved cognitive and motor functions in 3-NP-treated mice by reducing oxidative damage, cytokine levels, and enhancing mitochondrial activity. Higher doses (100 µM) were toxic to neuronal cells, while lower doses (5-20 mg/kg) were effective in vivo.
population_specificity: Neuro2a (N2a) cells and 3-NP-administered mice (n=6).
effective_dosage: 50 µM (in vitro), 5, 10, and 20 mg/kg (in vivo, p.o.).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the influence of capsaicin combined with stem cells on vitiligo treatment and confirm its molecular mechanism.
results_summary: Capsaicin combined with MSCs inhibited HSP70 expression, reduced TLR4 levels, and suppressed the mTOR/FAK pathway, improving mitochondrial function and autophagy in PIG3V cells. This combination promoted melanocyte proliferation and reduced apoptosis.
population_specificity: PIG3V cells (a vitiligo-related cell line)
